title: Reporting of Successful Video Playback - needs review
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video.
2. Let the video play for 30 seconds.
custom_expected:
In Touchstone>
1. A new session should be created when the user presses play.
2. When the video starts playing, a 'playing' state should be reported.
3. As the video progresses, the 'playing' state should continue to be reported.

title: Video Startup Time (with buffering) - needs review
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Use a tool (like Charles proxy) to throttle the CDN to a low bandwidth setting (eg: 200Kbps).
2. Press play on the video.
3. Wait for video to load (buffer) for 10 seconds, then release the throttle.
4. When video starts playing, check the "Video Startup Time" metric in Touchstone.
custom_expected:
In Touchstone> 
"Video Startup Time" should be displayed (in seconds) as the time between the user hitting play and the main content starting, including the initial buffering time.

title: Pausing of video - needs review
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video.
2. Once the main content starts playing, press the "Pause" button.
3. Unpause the video and let it continue.
custom_expected:
In Touchstone>
1. Verify that the monitoring session reports change to "Paused" state when user presses pause button.
2. Verify that the 'Playing time' stops increasing and the "Paused time" starts increasing.
3. Verify that the 'Paused time' stops increasing and the 'Playing time' starts increasing.

title: Stream failure at startup- needs review
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Use a web proxy tool (like Charles proxy) and configure a HTTP status 403 response to the video URL request for the manifest file.
2. Play the specific video, whose manifest has been blocked.
 
Note: 
(i) ‘Blacklist’ feature in Charles can be used to configure a 403 response. 
   
(ii) An alternate method is to ‘Map-remote’ the streamURL to a non-existent host (eg: foobar.com)
custom_expected:
Touchstone> 
1. When the user presses play, a new monitoring session should be created.
2. When the video fails to play (due to blocked request URL), a fatal error should be reported to Conviva library. 
3. Once the player has exhausted all retries (if any), the monitoring session should be cleaned up. 
Note: if the player has retry logic, all the retries (and their respective failure messages) should be reported in this same monitoring session. i.e. a new monitoring session should not be created for each retry.

title: Stream failure during playback - needs review
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video.
   
2. While the main content is playing, use a web proxy tool (like Charles proxy) to configure a HTTP status 403 response to the video URL request
 
Note:
(i) ‘Blacklist’ feature in Charles can be used to configure a 403 response.
(ii) An alternate method is to ‘Map-remote’ the streamURL to a non-existent host (eg: foobar.com)
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. When the user presses play, a new monitoring session should be created and the player states and events should start getting reported.
2. When the player runs into an error (due to blocked request URL), a fatal error should be reported to Conviva library.
3. Once the player has exhausted all retries (if any), the monitoring session should be cleaned up. 
Note: if the player has retry logic, all the retries (and their respective failure error messages) should be reported in this same monitoring session. i.e. a new monitoring session should not be created for each retry.

title: Reporting of Peak Bitrate values - needs review
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video.
2. Once the video starts playing at the highest bitrate, trigger a bitrate drop (by using a proxy tool like Charles proxy) to throttle down the bandwidth to CDN to a lower value (eg: 1000-1500Kbps).
3. Once the video switches to lower bitrate, unthrottle the network to let the video play again at highest bitrate.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. When the main content starts playing, verify that "Bitrate" (Kbps) value is displayed.
2. When the video switches to lower bitrate, verify that "Bitrate" value displays the new value.
3. When the video switches to higest bitrate, verify that "Bitrate" value displays the new value.

title: Report Buffering due to slow network - needs review
custom_preconds:
The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
Note: if the video is very short, you may need to start the video at lower bandwidth.
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video.
2. Once the main content starts playing, use a proxy tool (like Charles proxy) to throttle the bandwidth to CDN to a low value (eg: 100-200Kbps).
3. Once the player's buffer runs out, the player will display buffering icon to the user.
4. After 10 seconds, release the throttle so that the video can resume playing.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. When the player's buffer runs out and it displays a buffering icon to the user, verify that the session state is reported as "Buffering". 
2. Verify that the "Buffering time" increases with each heartbeat sent during this time.
3. When the video resumes, verify that the player reports state change from "Buffering" to "Playing".

title: User seek/scrub action - needs review
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Play video.
2. Seek the video forward or back by "clicking" at a new point on the progress bar in the video player.
3. When the video starts playing from the new point, seek the video forward or back again by "dragging" the playhead to a new point.
4. When the video starts playing from the new point, seek the video forward or back again by using the FF/RW buttons on the player.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. A new session should be created when user presses play.
2. When the user seeks by clicking, dragging or using the FF/RW buttons on the player, if any buffering is observed on screen, a 'buffering' state should be reported.
3. When the seek action was triggered, Player Seek Start (pss) and/or Player Seek End (pse) events should be reported
4. When the video resumes from the new point, a 'playing' state should be reported.

title: Backgrounding - needs review
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Play a video.
2. While the video is playing, for devices like SmartTVs, STBs and Gaming Consoles, press the home button to push the app to background. For desktop/web apps, minimize the browser or open a new tab to move the video to background.
3. Navigate back to the test application or the tab where the video was playing.
custom_expected:
Touchstone> There are 2 possible ways to handle this test scenario:

I - When the current session is not cleaned up:
1. When the app is pushed to Background, confirm that:
(a) Conviva.Analytics.reportAppBackgrounded() API is called.
(b) The session should not be cleaned up. 
(c) The app does not send any more heartbeats while in background. If it does, the player state should not be ‘Playing’ or ‘Buffering’. 
2. When the app is brought back to Foreground, confirm that:
(a) Conviva.Analytics.reportAppForegrounded() API is called.
(b) The appropriate player state is reported. If the video is paused, a ‘Paused’ state should be reported. If the video resumes, a ‘Playing’ state should be reported. 

II - When the current session is cleaned up:
1. When the app is pushed to Background, confirm that:
(a) The current session is cleaned up
2. When the app is brought back to Foreground, confirm that:
(a) If the video resumes, a new Conviva session should be created to track the video.

title: Verify handling of PiP mode - needs review
custom_preconds:
1. App should support PiP mode
2. The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Ensure PiP mode is enabled on the device and/or in the app. [NOTE: If PiP mode is not supported by the app, mark this test case as N/A]
2. Start playback for a video asset.
3. Once playback starts, press the home button to background the app (which should enable PiP mode).
4. Once the video starts playing in PiP mode, pause the video for 5 seconds and then resume the video.
5. Click the PiP button on the player to go back to the app (which also ends PiP mode).
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. When user presses play, a Conviva session should be created.
2. When the home button is pressed, the video should change to PiP mode and playback should continue. The Conviva session should also continue monitoring.
3. When the video is paused, a paused state should be reported to Conviva. When the video is resumed, a play state should be reported to Conviva.
4. When the user clicks on the PiP button on the player to go back to the app, the playback should continue and the Conviva session should also continue monitoring.

title: Close of Session - needs review
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Press play on a video.
2. While video is playing, exit the video using following methods:
- Press the Back or Home button on device/controller/remote. 
- Select another video while current video is playing.
- If using Chromecast, 'disconnect' the Chromecast from the casting device.
- If using a Browser, open a new URL (eg: www.google.com) in the same tab where the video is playing.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
1. When the user presses play, a new monitoring session should be created.
2. When the user exits the video, the monitoring session should be cleaned up and no more heartbeats should be sent in this session.

title: End of Session -  needs review
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Play video.
2. Let video play till the end. Note: you can seek the video forward to get closer to end of video
custom_expected:
Touchstone> 
Verify last HB is sent out and session is Ended. Note: sometimes session will not be cleaned up and will just timeout. It is ok as long as HBs are not constantly sent once the video is finished.

title: Confirm client library being used is latest - needs review
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Play a video.
2. Note the Conviva client library version being used. (visible in touchstone)
custom_expected:
In Touchstone>
Compare library version to that on Community website to make sure latest version is being used by the customer. If the latest version is not being used, fail this test and suggest the customer to update to the latest library.

title: Replay same video after End of Session - needs review
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Play a video.
2. Let the video play to the end (end of session). Note: You can scrub the video to move forward quicker.
3. Once the video ends, click 'replay/play' button to play the same video again.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
Verify initial session ends gracefully when video ends.
Verify new session is created for replayed video attempt.

title: Starting a new video during current playback - needs review
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Play a video.
2. While this video is playing, select another video from the UI.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
Verify current session ends when user selects another video.
Verify new session is created for the new video.

title: End of stream to next playlist item -  needs review
custom_preconds:
1. Auto-play/load feature needed
2. The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Play a video from the playlist.
2. Fast forward to near end of the video.
3. Let video play till end of stream and let next video in playlist auto-play.
custom_expected:
Touchstone>
Verify that a session is created for the video that has started.
Verify session is ended when playlist item ends. When next video starts loading, a new session should be created.

title: Verify CDN mapping on Conviva’s backend - needs review
custom_preconds:
NOTE: Repeat this test case for multiple VOD and LIVE assets. 


1. The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps:
1. Play a VOD video  
2. Once the video starts playing, find this session in Device Validation
custom_expected: 1. Confirm from Device Validation that we see a valid CDN mapped for this session, based on either **streamURL** or **Resource**.

title: Report unique FGUID for streaming sessions
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps: 1. Play a game
custom_expected:
In Touchstone>
1. A new session should be created when the user presses play.
2. A Unique ID is assigned to each streaming session and is listed under Tags as **fguid**. 

Test with several streams to make sure the ID is unique.

NOTE: This is Also passed to Adobe to link the records in the backend reporting.

title: Location Name
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps: 1. Press play on a video.
custom_expected:
In Touchstone>
1. **locationName** displays Finer grained CDN Information used to determine region/node

title: Client is passing Media Type in custom tags
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps: 1. Press play on a video.
custom_expected:
In Touchstone>
1. Media Type is displayed in the tracking object field **med** as either **audio** or **video**

title: Playback Scenario tracking. object field
custom_preconds: The application being tested should be configured to send data to touchstone.
custom_steps: 1. Play a game
custom_expected:
In Touchstone>
1. Playback Scenarios is displayed. under the tracking field object **pbs** and passes an MLB defined set of codecs and HTTP delivery mechanisms to stream media to platforms and consumers.

title: MGW Playback Session - Tracking Object and Conviva Metadata Mapping Verification
custom_steps:
1. Request a playback session from the Media Gateway (MGW).
2. Verify the presence of a tracking object in the response.
3. Validate the structure and data types of the tracking object.
4. Confirm the availability of properties for direct mapping as "custom" tags to Conviva.
5. Verify the accuracy of values in the "custom" tags by comparing with corresponding tracking object properties.
6. Identify properties requiring mapping to pre-defined Conviva tags.
7. Perform multiple variations of playback session requests to ensure consistency in tracking object structure and metadata mapping.
custom_expected:
The Media Gateway (MGW) returns a tracking object in the response for playback session requests. The tracking object has the necessary properties for metadata mapping to Conviva, including accurate values assigned to both "custom" tags and pre-defined Conviva tags. The Conviva metadata mapping accurately represents the streaming session details for analysis and monitoring purposes.

"tracking": {
  "assetName": "cg-sf-nyy-3-30-23",
  "categoryType": "Other",
  "contentType": "Archive",
  "fguid": "0b6075c8-2a83-49a7-96e6-109d074c5bd5",
  "isLive": "0",
  "med": "VIDEO",
  "locationName": null,
  "productType": "non-game",
  "pbs": "PLACEHOLDER",
  "plt": "WEB",
  "prt": "mlb",
  "state": "ON",
  "userId": "00ufd4bqjpgxTlgpL356",
  "contentRestrictions": "free",
  "adExperienceType": "None"
}

title: Validate SDK Key Constants for DM5 Tracking Object Field
custom_preconds:
The application is installed and running on the designated platform.
The DM5 Tracking Object Field is accessible and functional.
custom_steps:
1. Launch the application on the specified platform.
2. Navigate to the DM5 Tracking Object Field.
3. Verify the SDK key constant for the Asset Name field based on the platform:
---
For Android, confirm that the SDK key constant is set to ConvivaSdkConstants.ASSET_NAME.
For iOS/tvOS, confirm that the SDK key constant is set to CIS_SSDK_METADATA_ASSET_NAME.
For JavaScript, confirm that the SDK key constant is set to Conviva.Constants.ASSET_NAME.
For Roku, confirm that the SDK key constant is set to assetName.
For Xbox, confirm that the SDK key constant is set to assetName.
custom_expected:
On Android:
---
The SDK key constant for the Asset Name field should be ConvivaSdkConstants.ASSET_NAME.
On iOS/tvOS:
---
The SDK key constant for the Asset Name field should be CIS_SSDK_METADATA_ASSET_NAME.
On JavaScript:
---
The SDK key constant for the Asset Name field should be Conviva.Constants.ASSET_NAME.
On Roku:
---
The SDK key constant for the Asset Name field should be assetName.
On Xbox:
---
The SDK key constant for the Asset Name field should be assetName.

title: Verify Stream URL Constants for Different Platforms
custom_preconds:
1. The Conviva SDK is properly integrated into the application on the target platform.
2. The platform-specific SDK key constants are correctly set.
custom_steps:
1. Launch the application on the target platform.
2. Play a video stream using the Conviva SDK.
3.Retrieve the manifest URL or stream URL value from the Conviva SDK for the current video stream.
For Android:
---
a. Access the value of the ConvivaSdkConstants.STREAM_URL constant.
For iOS/tvOS:
---
a. Access the value of the CIS_SSDK_METADATA_STREAM_URL constant.
For JavaScript:
---
a. Access the value of the Conviva.Constants.STREAM_URL constant.
For Roku:
---
a. Access the value of the streamUrl variable.
For Xbox:
---
a. Access the value of the streamUrl variable.
custom_expected:
1. The application launches successfully on the target platform.
2. The video stream starts playing using the Conviva SDK.
3. The manifest URL or stream URL value is retrieved from the Conviva SDK for the current video stream.
4. The retrieved stream URL matches the expected value for the respective platform.

title: Test Case for Determining Stream Type (Live or VOD)
custom_preconds:
1. The application is installed and running on the respective platform (Android, iOS/tvOS, JavaScript, Roku, Xbox).
2. The Conviva SDK is integrated into the application.
3. A stream is available for testing.
custom_steps:
1. Launch the application.
2. Load the stream.
3. Access the SDK key constant or tracking object field specific to the platform being tested.

 For Android, check the value of ConvivaSdkConstants.IS_LIVE.
For iOS/tvOS, check the value of CIS_SSDK_METADATA_IS_LIVE.
For JavaScript, check the value of Conviva.Constants.IS_LIVE.
For Roku, check the value of isLive.
For Xbox, check the value of isLive.
For DM5 Tracking Object Field, check the value of isLive.

4. Verify the retrieved value matches the expected stream type (Live or VOD).
custom_expected:
1. The application launches successfully.
2. The stream loads without any errors.
3. The value of the SDK key constant or tracking object field matches the expected stream type (Live or VOD).

title: Verify Content Length Reporting for Various Platforms
custom_preconds:
1. The Conviva SDK is integrated into the application.
2. The platform-specific SDK key constants are correctly defined.
custom_steps:
1. Launch the application.
2. Start a video stream.
3. Retrieve the content length value from the Conviva SDK for the specific platform:

 **Android**: Access the ConvivaSdkConstants.DURATION constant.
**iOS/tvOS**: Access the CIS_SSDK_METADATA_DURATION constant.
**JavaScript**: Access the Conviva.Constants.DURATION constant.
**Roku**: Access the contentLength attribute.
**Xbox**: Access the duration attribute.
custom_expected:
1. The application should start successfully.
2. The video stream should begin playing.
3. The content length value retrieved from the Conviva SDK should match the expected value for the specific platform

title: App Name Consistency - Platform SDK Integration
custom_steps:
1. Review the platform-specific SDK documentation (Android, iOS/tvOS, JavaScript, Roku, Xbox) for the integration of the app name metadata.
2. Identify the designated variables or constants for reporting the app name on each platform:

   a. **Android**: ConvivaSdkConstants.PLAYER_NAME
b. **iOS/tvOS**: CIS_SSDK_METADATA_PLAYER_NAME
c. **JavaScript**: Conviva.Constants.PLAYER_NAME
d. **Roku**: playerName
e. **Xbox**: playerName
3. Verify that the app name metadata is correctly captured and reported by the platform SDK.
4. Ensure that the app name remains consistent throughout the DSS (Data Source System) and DM5 (Data Management System) for accurate player-to-player comparison, unless a new player implementation is introduced.
5. Validate that any changes to the app name are properly reflected in the platform-specific SDK implementations.
custom_expected: The platform SDK integration successfully captures and reports the app name using the designated variables or constants specific to each platform. The app name remains constant throughout the DSS and DM5, enabling accurate player-to-player comparison, unless a new player implementation is introduced. Any updates or changes to the app name are accurately reflected in the platform-specific SDK implementations. The app name reporting remains consistent across all supported platforms.

title: Viewer ID Reporting - Platform SDK Integration
custom_steps:
1. Review the platform-specific SDK documentation (Android, iOS/tvOS, JavaScript, Roku, Xbox) for the integration of the viewer ID metadata.
2. Identify the SDK Key Constants for reporting the viewer ID on each platform:

  a. **Android**: ConvivaSdkConstants.VIEWER_ID
b. **iOS/tvOS**: CIS_SSDK_METADATA_VIEWER_ID
c. **JavaScript**: Conviva.Constants.VIEWER_ID
d. **Roku**: viewerId
e. **Xbox**: viewerId
3. For identified users, ensure that the viewer ID corresponds to the Okta ID used by MLB.
4. For anonymous users, validate that either the deviceId or receiptId is provided as the viewer ID.
5. Verify that the viewer ID metadata is also recorded in the DM5 Tracking Object field "userId".
custom_expected: The viewer ID metadata is successfully captured and reported using the designated SDK Key Constants specific to each platform. For identified users, the viewer ID corresponds to the Okta ID used by MLB. For anonymous users, either the deviceId or receiptId is provided as the viewer ID. The viewer ID is recorded in the DM5 Tracking Object field "userId". Any updates or changes to the viewer ID are accurately reflected in both the SDK Key Constants and the DM5 Tracking Object. Consistent viewer ID reporting is maintained across all supported platforms.

title: Media Player Framework Name Detection
custom_preconds:
1. The application is installed and running on the respective platform (Android, iOS/tvOS, JavaScript, Roku, or Xbox).
2. The platform SDK is integrated into the application.
3. The Conviva SDK and its constants are available and accessible within the application.
custom_steps:
1. Launch the application.
2. Play a media file using the media player.
3. Verify that the media player framework name is collected and available.
custom_expected:
On Android:
---
The media player framework name should be collected and stored in ConvivaSdkConstants.FRAMEWORK_NAME.
The collected framework name should match the expected media player library name (ExoPlayer or any other supported library).

On iOS/tvOS:
---
The media player framework name should be collected and stored in CIS_SSDK_PLAYER_FRAMEWORK_NAME.
The collected framework name should match the expected media player library name.

JavaScript:
---
The media player framework name should be collected and stored in Conviva.Constants.FRAMEWORK_NAME.
The collected framework name should match the expected media player library name.

On Roku:
---
The media player framework name should be automatically collected.
The collected framework name should be unavailable (N/A) as stated in the provided information.

On Xbox:
---
The media player framework name should be automatically collected.
The collected framework name should be unavailable (N/A) as stated in the provided information.

title: Verify the Version of Media Player Framework
custom_preconds:
1. The application is installed and launched.
2. The Media Player Framework is integrated into the application.
3. The Media Player Framework version is available and accessible to the application.
custom_steps:
1. Launch the application.
2. Access the Media Player Framework version using the appropriate method or constant based on the platform.
---
For Android, retrieve the value of ConvivaSdkConstants.FRAMEWORK_VERSION.
For iOS/tvOS, retrieve the value of CIS_SSDK_PLAYER_FRAMEWORK_VERSION.
For JavaScript, retrieve the value of Conviva.Constants.FRAMEWORK_VERSION.
For Roku, verify that the value is not applicable (N/A) as it is automatically collected.
For Xbox, verify that the value is not reported.
custom_expected:
1. The application is successfully launched.
2. The Media Player Framework version is correctly retrieved based on the platform-specific method or constant.
---

For Android, the retrieved version matches the value of ConvivaSdkConstants.FRAMEWORK_VERSION
For iOS/tvOS, the retrieved version matches the value of CIS_SSDK_PLAYER_FRAMEWORK_VERSION
For JavaScript, the retrieved version matches the value of Conviva.Constants.FRAMEWORK_VERSION
For Roku, the Media Player Framework version is not applicable (N/A) - Autocollected.
For Xbox, the Media Player Framework version is not reported.

title: Connection Type Detection
custom_preconds:
1. The application is installed and running on the target device.
2. The device is connected to a stable network.
3. Test Connection Types: WiFi, Ethernet, 4G etc.
custom_steps:
1. Launch the application.
2. Navigate to the screen where the connection type is displayed or accessed.
3. Wait for the application to load and stabilize.
4. Verify that the Connection Type is displayed or logged, indicating the type of connection the user is on.
custom_expected:
Android:
---
The Connection Type is autocollected.
iOS/tVOS:
---
The Connection Type is collected using CIS_SSDK_PLAYBACK_METRIC_CONN_TYPE.

JavaScript:
---
The Connection Type is collected using Conviva.Constants.Network.CONNECTION_TYPE.

Roku:
---
The Connection Type is autocollected.

Xbox:
---
The Connection Type is autocollected.
